snippet.textDisplay: It works. I felt a push toward macs early on (designer here), but also being a gamer i had windows 'unwillingly'; but since adobe and now affinity apps are on windows, plus the gaming, recently i was looking for a tablet and wondered if there were any android\windows hybrids automatically- and even considered a windows one, just because it would be easy to use all the apps i already use, same enviroment, etc, etc. I never liked or trusted microsoft, but this strategy works. I used to have multiple systems on my boot, but ended up using ms so much more now i just have a linux on a stick i use less and less...

snippet.textDisplay: There's a much easier way to explain this. Windows does not cost users money because  it's no longer a product to Microsoft. It's a feature of their real product. You. We are no longer consumers, we are features. Their ability to extract the data about you that other companies are willing to pay for is more comprehensive and intrusive as at following you and even collecting data when you are in no way using a Microsoft product. If you have an android phone that you have ever connected to a Windows PC for any reason, like transferring mp3's Microsoft can, and almost definitely did add some cookie or found some open & exposed port and is collecting data on your android phone without the inconvenience  of having to use a Microsoft product or service to let Microsoft spy on you

snippet.textDisplay: You forgot to mention that the reason most Windows 7 users don't want to "upgrade" is that they don't want Windows 10's adware, spyware, and forced updates which often kick in right in the middle of work they're doing. If I ever have to migrate from 7 to another Microsoft product, it'll be 8.1 at the highest, I absolutely will not use Windows 10. And once 8.1 reaches EoL... who knows? I will NOT let Microsoft force me to install updates that can render my computer unusable.
snippet.textOriginal: You forgot to mention that the reason most Windows 7 users don't want to "upgrade" is that they don't want Windows 10's adware, spyware, and forced updates which often kick in right in the middle of work they're doing.  If I ever have to migrate from 7 to another Microsoft product, it'll be 8.1 at the highest, I absolutely will *not* use Windows 10.  And once 8.1 reaches EoL... who knows?  I will *NOT* let Microsoft *force* me to install updates that can render my computer unusable.

snippet.textDisplay:
My rant is just on how inferior Windows is from a programmer's perspective. I've been fighting to get software to compile with Visual Studio the last few days. The amount of bullshit and non-standard platform specific crap I've had to add to my build scripts just to appease MSVC has made me want to blow my brains out. Windows' dynamic linker doesn't support backlinking either, like POSIX does. So I have to link all my extensions with most of the same DLLs as the program they plug into, though that's more of just a nuisance. And a pragma in the source to dynamically link to a DLL? Really? I knew about it for some time but didn't realize how few alternative options you have when using MSVC for your toolchain.
Not to mention dependency hell is 1000% worse with MSVC, since there's no good package management and everything in NuGet is old and crusty and/or infected. And lastly, even if you can use MinGW like I usually do, some newer Win32 functions are not available due to a lack of maintenance. And then you get to deal with the various libstdc++/msvc runtime collisions.
snippet.textOriginal:
My rant is just on how inferior Windows is from a programmer's perspective. I've been fighting to get software to compile with Visual Studio the last few days. The amount of bullshit and non-standard platform specific crap I've had to add to my build scripts just to appease MSVC has made me want to blow my brains out. Windows' dynamic linker doesn't support backlinking either, like POSIX does. So I have to link all my extensions with most of the same DLLs as the program they plug into, though that's more of just a nuisance. And a pragma in the source to dynamically link to a DLL? Really? I knew about it for some time but didn't realize how few alternative options you have when using MSVC for your toolchain.
Not to mention dependency hell is 1000% worse with MSVC, since there's no good package management and everything in NuGet is old and crusty and/or infected. And lastly, even if you can use MinGW like I usually do, some newer Win32 functions are not available due to a lack of maintenance. And then you get to deal with the various libstdc++/msvc runtime collisions.
